Firstly, it is important to understand the size of the Stanford Linear Accelerator (SLAC) and the Golden Gate Bridge. 

The SLAC is approximately 2 miles long and weighs around 2,000 tons. 

On the other hand, the Golden Gate Bridge is approximately 1.7 miles long and has a weight capacity of 6,000 tons. 

Based on these figures, it is clear that the weight of the SLAC alone exceeds the weight capacity of the Golden Gate Bridge. Therefore, even if we disregard the length of the SLAC, it is impossible for it to fit on the bridge due to its weight. 

Hence, the correct answer is (B) no.

First, we need to consider the size of the Stanford Linear Accelerator. It is a particle accelerator that is approximately 2 miles (3.2 kilometers) long, and has a diameter of about 6 feet (1.8 meters). 

Next, we need to look at the size of the Golden Gate Bridge. The bridge has a total length of 1.7 miles (2.7 kilometers) and a width of 90 feet (27 meters). 

Clearly, the Stanford Linear Accelerator is much longer than the Golden Gate Bridge, but it is also much narrower. There is no way that the entire length of the accelerator could fit on the bridge, and even if it could, it would not be safe to do so. 

Therefore, the answer to the question is (B) no, the Stanford Linear Accelerator will not fit on the Golden Gate Bridge.
